newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Shenzhen B index firms at noon on economic data.
newsitem.headline: Shenzhen B index firms at noon on economic data.

text.p: Shenzhen's hard currency B share index firmed at midday on Tuesday, with positive economic forecasts for the first half of 1997 from Beijing boosting sentiment, brokers said.
The index rose 2.37 points or 1.31 percent to 183.50 on turnover of HK$115 million.

China's gross domestic product is expected to grow 9.6 percent year-on-year in the first half, with retail price inflation seen at two percent, the Beijing-based Financial News said on Tuesday, quoting a forecast by the Information Department of the State Economic and Trade Commission.
"Investors are betting on good 1997 interim earnings from listed firms given China's booming economy," an analyst at China Guotai Securities Co said.
Three B share listings in Shenzhen scheduled for later this month are expected to further boost sentiment and push the B index up through the 200-point level, analysts said.

Pesticide maker Hubei Sanonda Co Ltd, Shandong Chenming Paper Holdings Ltd and Nanjing Posts & Telecommunications Equipment Co Ltd have announced they will each offer 100 million B shares for listing later this month.
"The three firms are expected to post strong debuts on listing because of their solid earnings and the market's recent bullishness," an analyst at Shenzhen J&A Securities said.
"Their expected strong debuts will in turn boost the index," the J&A analyst added.
On the B share market, Shenzhen SEG maintained its strong upward momentum on institutional demand due to optimism over the colour television tube maker's 1997 interim earnings, brokers said.
The share, the session's sharpest gainer, rose HK$0.57 or 5.83 percent to HK$10.35 on volume of 1.38 million shares.
The domestic A share index climbed 12.78 points or 2.52 percent to 520.66 as the market's recent rises sparked inflows of fresh capital, brokers said. Turnover in the morning was 9.57 billion yuan.
The A share market leader, Shenzhen Development Bank, soared 10 percent to 44.47 yuan on heavy volume of 20.46 million shares.

Shenzhen Development Bank's sharp gains follow an item in the Shenzhen-based Securities Times on Monday which quoted the bank's president He Yun as forecasting a strong rise in the firm's 1997 earnings.
